Award.AwardTitle: Fully-Implicit Time Stepping Methods with Integrated Proximity Queries for Accurate Simulation of Multi-Rigid-Body Systems with Intermittent Contact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
To automatically plan tasks involving contact between objects, accurate prediction of object motions is essential. Applications include collaborative human-robot manipulation, industrial automation, engineering design, and physics engines for computer games. The intermittency of contact and stick-slip behavior make it difficult to simulate multibody systems stably and accurately. Commercially available multibody simulation software has difficulty simulating even simple systems with contacts. As a result, users must resort to trial-and-error to find simulation parameters that yield believable, not necessarily accurate, results. The algorithms developed in this research project will lead to improved future versions of simulation products such as Adams and Working Model.

The primary sources of stability and accuracy problems in multibody simulation are polyhedral representations of smooth objects, decoupling of collision detection from the solution of the dynamic time-stepping subproblem, linearization of Coulomb friction model, and errors in model parameters. This research focuses on formulations, algorithm development and analysis of time-steppers to eliminate the first three error sources. The result will be a fully-implicit, stable, accurate, optimization approach to simulating systems of rigid objects undergoing intermittent contact; the objects will be modeled using implicit and parametric surface representations. No previous general method has been developed that combines dynamics and geometric constraints in a fully-implicit manner. By using the new time-stepper as a ``ground truth" model, all previous models can be compared, so that for the first time, the error effects of the most common approximations can be quantified. This research will involve graduate and undergraduate students. The results will be incorporated into our simulation package and introduced in the robotics courses at RPI.
Outreach activities include summer Lego robotics activities for middle school students.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The period from 1 September 2011 to 31 August 2012 was focused on starting a new research collaboration with robotics researchers in Germany.  The Principal Investigator (PI) spent the summers of 2011 and 2012 pursuing this goal in the Autonomous Systems Laboratory of Prof. Wolfram Burgard at the University of Freiburg in Freiburg, Germany.

The accomplishments are as follows: (1) a proposal was written with Prof. Burgard and funded by the Ministry for Arts and Sciences in the State of Badenwuertemberg to support the PI as Guest Professor for Autonomous Manipulation at the University of Freiburg, (2) the PI participated in a proposal to the German Research Foundation on the topic of using humans in robot control loops to ehnahce robots' levels of perception and manipulation skills, and (3) one of the PI's phd students spent four weeks with the PI in Freiburg working with a Prof. Burgard, me, and a German phd student.

The funding successes will support continued collaboration between the PI and Prof. Burgard's lab through the summer of 2016.  Currently, we are writing a joint paper on the use of Gaussian Process Models to understand the traction of legged robots running on granular terrain, ground covered with a layer of loose stones.


Last Modified: 09/11/2012
Modified by: Jeffrey Trinkle

Images (1 of )
  • A robot steps onto a patch of granular terrain. Force and motion data is gathered to train a Gaussian Process model to characterize the traction available to the robot as it runs across such terrain.
    CS Robotics Lab, RPI, Troy, NY, USA.
    Public Domain
    Jeffrey Trinkle
    Granular Terrain Traction Experiment
  • The data gathered by a force sensor in the ankle of the robot leg is fit to the Tustin friction model. Data points are colored blue or green to indicate sticking contact or slipping contact.
    CS Robotics Lab, RPI, Troy, NY, USA.
    Public Domain
    Jeffrey Trinkle
    Ground Force versus Slipping Speed

The accomplishments are as follows: (1) a proposal was written with Prof. Burgard and funded by the Ministry for Arts and Sciences in the State of Badenwuertemberg to support the PI as Guest Professor for Autonomous Manipulation at the University of Freiburg, (2) the PI participated in a proposal to the German Research Foundation on the topic of using humans in robot control loops to ehnahce robots' levels of perception and manipulation skills, and (3) one of the PI's phd students spent four weeks with the PI in Freiburg working with a Prof. Burgard, me, and a German phd student. The funding successes will support continued collaboration between the PI and Prof. Burgard's lab through the summer of 2016. Currently, we are writing a joint paper on the use of Gaussian Process Models to understand the traction of legged robots running on granular terrain, ground covered with a layer of loose stones.
